So before I realized there are radial parachutes out there now, I've been trying to figure out how to build a completely recoverable craft that was capable of orbiting and all parts returning safely to Kearth. The first design is the ML Recoverable Launch Vehicle I (RLV-I).

The radial decouplers holding the mini boosters are set to stage 0 and meant to be purely a support structure. At the top of each mini SRB is a tri-canopy parachute unit, and the boosters are fired upon launch to minimize excess weight immediately.

The landing struts are angled so as to not be destroyed by the SRBs, and the SRBs are angle so as not to destroy the struts.

Despite the low impact threshold for Sunday Punch's extended tanks, the landing impact is slowed enough that it spreads easily through the three tanks.

This of course lead to something a bit more complicated. Because, why the hell wouldn't it?

The RLV-II has the RLV-I at its core. Literally. Right smack dab in the middle and everything:

The big solid boosters have parachutes, and a high-enough impact threshold, they usually survive. On top of the RLV-II is the reusable command module. Like the RLV-I it also takes advantage of the radial-decouplers-as-parachute-holding-thingies design, and initial testing showed it was capable of safely landing even with the weight of a full liquid fuel tank, as well as full solid boosters:

Which is of course what the fine folks at Mockheed Lartin meant to do. Safety first, and all that! This means if a launch fails to make orbit, you don't have to fight a rocket just so you can burn out your tanks and land, you can fall right out of the sky immediately. This means a quicker turn-around for astronauts, which unfortunately are hard to train.
